Eulogized

The first debate of the newly
reorganized society of the Hopkins will be held this afternoon
at 4.00 P. M. in Levering Hall,
when the local team meets two
Englishmen, who are scheduled
to meet representatives of many
of the major colleges of the country on the tour which they are
making.
Unemployment Is Topic
Leo Alpert and Charles Squire
are the Hopkins debaters. They
wll defend the negative on the
question "Resolved: That the doie
provides a better solution of the
unemployment problem than does
th charity system." Both men are
to give 20 minute constructive
speeches, and a six minute rebuttal wll be made by Albert.
The two Englishmen have been
sent to America by the National
Union of English Students. They
were chosen from the many universities who are associated with
the Union as being the most capable debaters. Stuart Craig received his degree from University
College, Nottingham, and John
Needham completed Durham University.
Englishmen Are Versatile
Craig took his A. B. degree
with Honors in Philosophy. He
has taken a leading part in the
Students' Union, and is at present head of the organization. He
was also Secretary and then
President of the Students' Christian Union.
The other visitor, John .Needham, has also held many student
offices, being Vice-Senior of his
Class and President of the Durham chapter of the Union.
Are Varsity Athletes
Both men are athletes. Craig having been on the varsity hockey,
rifle and golf teams, while Needham was captain of the rowing
squad and also played Rugger
and Association football, Cricket
and Rocky.
The two men arrive at noon at
th Pennsylvania Station and are
to be received by members of the
Hopkins
Society's
Receptior
Committee. They will be enter
tained at a luncheon in Levering
Hall, at which all the members
of the Debating Class will be present. In the evening, they will be
taken to a supper ' and show.
A large crowd is expected, as
there has been a large demand
for the tickets of admission.
These must be procured from the
Y. M. C. A. desk or from the
Treasurer's Office.
Open Forum Schedule
Dean Berry has been chosen
to preside at the contest, which
is to be a no-decision affair.
After the speakers have finished,
the meeting will be thrown open
for questions from the floor.

Reelections To Take Place On Thursday; Revised List Of Nominations
Appears
Due to the fact that an omissio!'l
of names occurred on the list of
nominees, the Sophomore election
which took place last Thursday,
was declared void. It appeared
that the names of Reed and Phillips, for the respective offices of
Vice-President and Sergeant-atarms, did not appear on the list for
election.
President Oscar Helm of the
Student Council declared, after the
omission was drawn to his attention, that a re-election will take
place on Thursday co-inceclental
with that of the Junior Class. Nominations, however, will not be reopened.
The revised list of nominations
follows:
President-Falck, Curtwright.
Vice-Ptesident-C. Stern, Whittaker, H. Lee, B. Reed.
Secretary-T. Stern, L. Harris,
Hill, Jenkins, Barger.
Treasurer-D. Kelly, Heally.
Sergeant-at-Arms-Carter, Phillips, Cohen, Heaney, Gladding.

DITO RIALS
COLLEGE SPIRIT
It was clearly evidenced last
week that the spirit of the University is not entirely latent. The
happenings of last Thursday night,
althoug·h not entirely unheard of
before, were on a larger scale than
the tussles of previous years.
Last year a small body of Hopkins' students drove down to. Annapolis and attempted to incinerate
the huge pile of boxwood that had
been piled high by the St. John's
students. On this pile "Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins" was later burned
in effigy. The attempts of the
Hopkins students to burn the wood
were unsuccessful and a tussle between the students and Annapolis
police ensued and a couple men
were taken to the lock-up for the
night, but were later released.
The situation this year was on a
much larger scale and involved a
greater number of students. A
large group of the Hopkins men
were thrown into the jail while
only a couple St. John's men were
put in the lock-up. Why this should
have happened we cannot understand. We feel that if the police
and firem1m had allowed the students of the two institutions to have
their tussles and had not interfered,
that a great amount of the extra
rumpus would not have occurred
and none of the students would
have been jailed or fined. The law
and the fire department have their
place in society, are a necessity and
do an untold amount of good to the
furthering of civilization and the
protection of property, but we feel
that they should haYe adopted a
policy of "hands off" and allowed
the fracas to reach its natural end
without their assistance.

---o--GOOD WORK
The jinx which had o'ershadowed
the John Hopkins football team for
the past three years was on a vacation last Saturday, and the Jays
gave the Crabtown eleven a decided trouncing when they met for
their annual tussel on the gridiron.
The score of 20 to 13 does not denote a victory with a agreat margin,
but the Johnnies took an awful
beating from the hands of the Jays
which they will not soon forget.
In 1928 and 1929 they defeated
us by large scores and last year, on
a very sloppy field, the Johnnies
were able to register four touch-·
downs to our one. This year the
snake seems to have turned and it

Students at Union College may
play golf on week days throughout
the year at a local golf club for
the modest fee of $10. Freshmen
and sophomores may substitute this
for regular gym classes.

"Resolved : That it is better to
be dtunk than to be in love," was
the topic of a recent formal debate
at McGill University. Although
the topic has been debated informally many times, this was the first
formal attempt.

Victor Serunian, a freshman at
the University of North Carolina
and ·a native of Persia, says that
American girls are the prettiest he
has ever seen. He attributed the
American feminine beauty to athletics.

Park Dickey Describes Savage
Before Meeting Of Geologists
Tells Of Habits Of Goagiro Tribe Who Conform In
Wearing Coat But Draw
Line At Trousers
Describing one of the most
savage of the Indian tribes of
South America, which he had
personally visited, Mr. Park
Dickey spoke to the geologists of
tl1e Johns Hopkins who gathered
at Dean Edward W. Berry's home
iast Saturday night.
Tells of Belligerent Tribe

"The Goajiros are one of the
more advanced, but scarcely less
belligerent tribes who inhabit the
broad plains scarcely a day's journew north of Maracaibo, a modern, thriving city of one hundred
thousand people, of Venezuela,"
.Mr. Dickey, who made the trip to
the Goajiro tribe last summer,
began his discussion. "Until only
a very few years ago few Colombians or Venezuelans dared set
foot in their territory, and many
and bloody have been the battles
between the Spaniards and these
Indians.
"The Goajiros," Mr. Dickey
continued, "are nomadic in habit,
and have huge flocks of fine cattle, sheep and goats. The ubiquitous "burro" is also used as a
beast of burden. The men, who
ride .on splendid horses, are of
medium stature, and stocky and
well built. The women are . often
surprisingly good looking when
they don't paint daubs of red and
black on their faces. , The men
rarely wear more than a loincloth, though they have a garment resembling a Roman tunic
for state occasions. When they
come to Maracaibo to trade they
conform to civilized practice in
wearing a coat, but draw the line
at trousers. The women wear
long, flowing robes, often of fine
material.

spine of the stingray, coated with
snake poison, and rotten flesh,
and aided with a good deal 0£
magic," Mr. Dickey said. "vVhen
a war breaks out among the
tribes, it is very dangerous for
outsiders. With a few exceptions,
they were friendly to me, ho-wever."
"In common with many South
AtQerican tribes the inheritance
is .not from fat-her to son but
[rom the maternal uncle to the
nephew. The basis for this seems
to be the belief that a child is
more closely related to his mother than to his father, and one's
sister's children are nearer relations than one's own childr:en.
Thus the women have much
standing in the community, and
are often consulted in affairs o E
state," he added.

People Too Easily Impressed
By Pomp Of
Officialdom
Dr. Broadus Mitchell, in an address before the Liberal Club last
Friday, took as his topic the much
discussed subject of "Liberal-Mindedness'', and gave it his usual ~rigi­
nal interesting interpretation, Dr.
Mitchell defined the liberal as,
~'One who is willing to regard
!Social relations subject to rapid and
frequent unaccountable change".
He stressed the difficulty of distinguishing between what is morally right and wrong. Right and
wrong are relative, and the moral
code is set by existing and changing conditions.
Traces Illiberality

He traced much of the extreme
illiberality that exists today to the
need that people feel for some
straw of dogma to cling to, "as a
drowning per.son clings to wreck-·
age." They find themselves casi
suddenly upon a world of startling
breadth of opinions, and seize desperately at any anchor of morai
principle, be that principle suited
to modern conditions, or not.
The shortness and basic unimportance of the average life is, according to Dr. Mitchell, a potent
factor in the development of liberal~
ism. The proper course is for
people to recognise the presence
and necessity of change and to aid
in turning the course of that change
in the right direction. The course
of events can be directed, not
stopped. This course of events is
what we call progress, although we
call the liberals who advocate the
quiet acceptance of this progress
radicals.

The first debate of the newly
reorganized society of the Hopkins will be held this afternoon
at 4.00 P. M. in Levering Hall,
when the local team meets two
Englishmen, who are scheduled
to meet representatives of many
of the major colleges of the country on the tour which they are
making.
Unemployment Is Topic
Leo Alpert and Charles Squire
are the Hopkins debaters. They
wll defend the negative on the
question "Resolved: That the doie
provides a better solution of the
unemployment problem than does
th charity system." Both men are
to give 20 minute constructive
speeches, and a six minute rebuttal wll be made by Albert.
The two Englishmen have been
sent to America by the National
Union of English Students. They
were chosen from the many universities who are associated with
the Union as being the most capable debaters. Stuart Craig received his degree from University
College, Nottingham, and John
Needham completed Durham University.
Englishmen Are Versatile
Craig took his A. B. degree
with Honors in Philosophy. He
has taken a leading part in the
Students' Union, and is at present head of the organization. He
was also Secretary and then
President of the Students' Christian Union.
The other visitor, John .Needham, has also held many student
offices, being Vice-Senior of his
Class and President of the Durham chapter of the Union.
Are Varsity Athletes
Both men are athletes. Craig having been on the varsity hockey,
rifle and golf teams, while Needham was captain of the rowing
squad and also played Rugger
and Association football, Cricket
and Rocky.
The two men arrive at noon at
th Pennsylvania Station and are
to be received by members of the
Hopkins
Society's
Receptior
Committee. They will be enter
tained at a luncheon in Levering
Hall, at which all the members
of the Debating Class will be present. In the evening, they will be
taken to a supper ' and show.
A large crowd is expected, as
there has been a large demand
for the tickets of admission.
These must be procured from the
Y. M. C. A. desk or from the
Treasurer's Office.
Open Forum Schedule
Dean Berry has been chosen
to preside at the contest, which
is to be a no-decision affair.
After the speakers have finished,
the meeting will be thrown open
for questions from the floor.

DITO RIALS
COLLEGE SPIRIT
It was clearly evidenced last
week that the spirit of the University is not entirely latent. The
happenings of last Thursday night,
althoug·h not entirely unheard of
before, were on a larger scale than
the tussles of previous years.
Last year a small body of Hopkins' students drove down to. Annapolis and attempted to incinerate
the huge pile of boxwood that had
been piled high by the St. John's
students. On this pile "Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins" was later burned
in effigy. The attempts of the
Hopkins students to burn the wood
were unsuccessful and a tussle between the students and Annapolis
police ensued and a couple men
were taken to the lock-up for the
night, but were later released.
The situation this year was on a
much larger scale and involved a
greater number of students. A
large group of the Hopkins men
were thrown into the jail while
only a couple St. John's men were
put in the lock-up. Why this should
have happened we cannot understand. We feel that if the police
and firem1m had allowed the students of the two institutions to have
their tussles and had not interfered,
that a great amount of the extra
rumpus would not have occurred
and none of the students would
have been jailed or fined. The law
and the fire department have their
place in society, are a necessity and
do an untold amount of good to the
furthering of civilization and the
protection of property, but we feel
that they should haYe adopted a
policy of "hands off" and allowed
the fracas to reach its natural end
without their assistance.

The score of 20 to 13 does not denote a victory with a agreat margin,
but the Johnnies took an awful
beating from the hands of the Jays
which they will not soon forget.

us by large scores and last year, on
a very sloppy field, the Johnnies
were able to register four touch-·
downs to our one. This year the

Park Dickey Describes Savage
Before Meeting Of Geologists
Tells Of Habits Of Goagiro Tribe Who Conform In
Wearing Coat But Draw
Line At Trousers
Describing one of the most
savage of the Indian tribes of
South America, which he had
personally visited, Mr. Park
Dickey spoke to the geologists of
tl1e Johns Hopkins who gathered
at Dean Edward W. Berry's home
iast Saturday night.
Tells of Belligerent Tribe

"The Goajiros are one of the
more advanced, but scarcely less
belligerent tribes who inhabit the
broad plains scarcely a day's journew north of Maracaibo, a modern, thriving city of one hundred
thousand people, of Venezuela,"
.Mr. Dickey, who made the trip to
the Goajiro tribe last summer,
began his discussion. "Until only
a very few years ago few Colombians or Venezuelans dared set
foot in their territory, and many
and bloody have been the battles
between the Spaniards and these
Indians.
"The Goajiros," Mr. Dickey
continued, "are nomadic in habit,
and have huge flocks of fine cattle, sheep and goats. The ubiquitous "burro" is also used as a
beast of burden. The men, who
ride .on splendid horses, are of
medium stature, and stocky and
well built. The women are . often
surprisingly good looking when
they don't paint daubs of red and
black on their faces. , The men
rarely wear more than a loincloth, though they have a garment resembling a Roman tunic
for state occasions. When they
come to Maracaibo to trade they
conform to civilized practice in
wearing a coat, but draw the line
at trousers. The women wear
long, flowing robes, often of fine
material.

and aided with a good deal 0£
magic," Mr. Dickey said. "vVhen
a war breaks out among the
tribes, it is very dangerous for
outsiders. With a few exceptions,
they were friendly to me, ho-wever."
"In common with many South
AtQerican tribes the inheritance
is .not from fat-her to son but
[rom the maternal uncle to the
nephew. The basis for this seems
to be the belief that a child is
more closely related to his mother than to his father, and one's
sister's children are nearer relations than one's own childr:en.
Thus the women have much
standing in the community, and
are often consulted in affairs o E
state," he added.

STRESSES DANGER
OF MASS CONTEMPT
People Too Easily Impressed
By Pomp Of
Officialdom
Dr. Broadus Mitchell, in an address before the Liberal Club last
Friday, took as his topic the much
discussed subject of "Liberal-Mindedness'', and gave it his usual ~rigi­
nal interesting interpretation, Dr.
Mitchell defined the liberal as,
~'One who is willing to regard
!Social relations subject to rapid and
frequent unaccountable change".
He stressed the difficulty of distinguishing between what is morally right and wrong. Right and
wrong are relative, and the moral
code is set by existing and changing conditions.
Traces Illiberality

He traced much of the extreme
illiberality that exists today to the
need that people feel for some
straw of dogma to cling to, "as a
drowning per.son clings to wreck-·
age." They find themselves casi
suddenly upon a world of startling
breadth of opinions, and seize desperately at any anchor of morai
principle, be that principle suited
to modern conditions, or not.
The shortness and basic unimportance of the average life is, according to Dr. Mitchell, a potent
factor in the development of liberal~
ism. The proper course is for
people to recognise the presence
and necessity of change and to aid
in turning the course of that change
in the right direction. The course
of events can be directed, not
stopped. This course of events is
what we call progress, although we
call the liberals who advocate the
quiet acceptance of this progress
radicals.

Some time was d~voted to the

benificent workers for the human

around the country in the cause of
the unfortunates of the economic
system. People are too easily impressed by the pomp of officialdom.
They are only human, and, "No
an is a hero to his valet."

Addressing a group of about
150 students and graduates last
Friday, Dr. Leo H. Baekeland,
internationally renowned scientist, confessed that one of his
greatest errors in youth was his
being too certain of the things
which enthused him.
"I loved theories - I was too
dogmatic and cocksure about
everything. But the advantage of
age is experience. I know better
now. Youth is quick to perceive
and rapid in action-but their inability to profit by the mistakes
of their predecessors is the great
tragedy of the human race!"
Depression Child's Play
Dr. Baekeland, speaking of the
present depression, said that it is
mere child's play compared with
that which occurred in 1893. He
said that the setbacks he encountered during that critical period
gave him a greater incentive to
work harder, and to succeed in
his chosen profession. He declared that no greater boon than depression can happen to people
starting out in life.
\iVhen he produced the revolutionizing product, Velox, people
laughed, said Dr. Baekeland. They
didn't want to change their ideas.

tied up in industrial chemistry."
\i\Then you get more than you

couldn't remain with my pure
science."
